LOCAL TITLE: PC - AFTERVISIT SUMMARY STANDARD TITLE: PRIMARY CARE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: MAR 17, 2023@09:27 ENTRY DATE: MAR 17, 2023@09:27:06 AUTHOR: TESTjones,LISA M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** CLINIC AFTERVISIT SUMMARY ***
MHVZZVISNTWENTY,TEST PATIENTR
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your healthcare. Please review this document. It may contain additional information or instructions from your care provider. _______________________________________________________________________
PATIENT INSTRUCTIONS:
Thank you for coming in
Please report for labs
Please monitor your blood pressure and blood glucose
We will meet again in 3 months
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
THIS IS YOUR MEDICATION LIST MAR 17, 2023 You should keep a copy of your medication list and bring it with you to all of your medical appointments. Please continue to take these medications as directed. Call us or send us a secure message if you start, stop, or change medications. To help your primary care team provide the safest care for you, it is important for them to know about all the medications you take, even if it's just an herbal supplement or over the counter medications.
If you have any questions, please notify an assistant before you leave. If you need to refill a medication, please call 1-888-400-8387
_______________________________________________________________________
NEW AND DISCONTINUED MEDICATIONS
Your provider has NOT prescribed any new medications today.
_______________________________________________________________________
Your provider has NOT discontinued any of your medications today.
_______________________________________________________________________
CONTINUED MEDICATIONS (active VA and non-VA meds)
These medications were not changed during this visit. You should continue to take them as prescribed. Active Medications ============================================================ 1) Acetaminophen 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth four times a day as needed *do Not take more than 4,000mg a day of acetaminophen From all sources due to risk of liver damage. 2) Albuterol 100/Ipratro 20Mcg 120D Po Inhl Inhale 1 spray by mouth four times a day (each inhaler Contains 120 sprays) 3) Allopurinol 100Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 4) Aspirin 325Mg Ec Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 5) Buspirone Hcl 10Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth twice a day as needed for anxiety 6) Capsaicin 0.1% Cream Apply a small amount topically twice a day 7) Clopidogrel Bisulfate 75Mg Tab Take one tablet every day 8) Diphenhydramine Hcl 25Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth four times a day as needed 9) Fluoxetine Hcl 10Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth every day 10) Fluticas 500/Salmeterol 50 Inhl Disk 60 Inhale 1 inhalation by mouth twice a day rinse mouth and Spit after use. Discard 1 month after opening foil pouch. 11) Folic Acid 1Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 12) Glipizide 5Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth twice a day for diabetes. Take 30 Minutes before a meal. 13) Hydrochlorothiazide 25Mg Tab Take two tablets by mouth every morning for blood pressure 14) Hydrocortisone 1% Cream Apply thin film topically every day 15) Ibuprofen 400Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth three times a day as needed 16) Insulin Reg 100U/ml Inj 10Ml Vl Inject 5 units subcutaneously as directed 17) Metformin Hcl 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 18) Metoprolol Succinate 25Mg Sa Tab Take two tablets by mouth every day 19) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day 20) Omeprazole 20Mg Ec Cap Take one capsule by mouth every day 21) Pioglitazone Hcl 15Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 22) Pravastatin Na 80Mg Tab Take one-half tablet by mouth every evening to lower your Cholesterol 23) Tamsulosin Hcl 0.4Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth at bedtime 24) Tiotropium 18Mcg Inhl Cap 30 Place 1 capsule (18 mcg) in inhaler, inhale by mouth every Day replaces ipratropium (atrovent/combivent), for Inhaler use only
Active Non-VA Medications: ============================================================ 1) Acetaminophen 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth 2) Amiodarone Hcl (Pacerone) 200Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 3) Aspirin Take by mouth every day 4) Clopidogrel Bisulfate 75Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth 5) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day
You have 29 active medications
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Your Primary Care Provider is: Unknown
#FUTURE APPOINTMENTS: Future Appointments: No future appointments on file
#LABS that were ordered today: No pending labs.
#IMAGING STUDIES that were ordered in the last 3 months: NO recent pending Radiology found.
+ If an imaging study (ultrasound, CT, MRI, etc) has been ordered, please call the Portland VA Medical Center Imaging Scheduling number to make arrangements: 503-273-5126.
#CONSULTS or PROCEDURES that were ordered in the past week: NO recent pending Consults found.
Your health care team may have discussed whether or not you were exposed to any potential toxins/hazards during your military service during this visit.
This is related to a new Toxic Exposure Screening (TES) program in the VA. If you believe you were exposed to potential toxins/hazards during your service, you can go here to learn more about what the VA is doing to support our Veterans: https://www.warrelatedillness.va.gov/WARRELATEDILLNESS/education/local-off erings/support/ToxicExposureScreeningEnglish.pdf
If you believe you were exposed to agent orange, burn pits, other airborne hazards, radiation, or served in Gulf War theaters, you may be eligible to participate in a free registry exam. You may call 503-906-5100 for more information.
For Healthcare Eligibility and Enrollment questions, contact our Enrollment Office at 503-273-5069.
For questions about Benefits and Claims you can find a Veteran Service Organization Office near you at: https://www.ebenefits.va.gov/ebenefits/vso-search or by calling VBA 1-800-827-1000.
If you are interested in physical therapy, please call the number below to arrange an appointment: All clinics: (503)273-5018
Your vitals for today are: Blood Pressure - 125/80 (01/08/2020 14:27) Weight - 255 lb [115.67 kg] (01/08/2020 14:27) Pain Level - 0 (01/08/2020 14:27) _______________________________________________________________________
If you have questions or concerns after today, please contact the clinic by calling 1-800-949-1004. Select option 2 when the automated message starts.

*** CLINIC AFTERVISIT SUMMARY ***
MHVZZVISNTWENTY,TEST PATIENTR
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your healthcare. Please review this document. It may contain additional information or instructions from your care provider. _______________________________________________________________________
PATIENT INSTRUCTIONS:
Thank you for coming in.
Please continue to be active most days of the week.
Continue making healthy meal choices for your nutrition.
Let us know if you would like to come back for any vaccines.
Thank you, Dr TESTjones
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
THIS IS YOUR MEDICATION LIST JAN 27, 2023 You should keep a copy of your medication list and bring it with you to all of your medical appointments. Please continue to take these medications as directed. Call us or send us a secure message if you start, stop, or change medications. To help your primary care team provide the safest care for you, it is important for them to know about all the medications you take, even if it's just an herbal supplement or over the counter medications.
If you have any questions, please notify an assistant before you leave. If you need to refill a medication, please call 1-888-400-8387
_______________________________________________________________________
NEW AND DISCONTINUED MEDICATIONS
Your provider has NOT prescribed any new medications today.
_______________________________________________________________________
Your provider has NOT discontinued any of your medications today.
_______________________________________________________________________
CONTINUED MEDICATIONS (active VA and non-VA meds)
These medications were not changed during this visit. You should continue to take them as prescribed. Active Medications ============================================================ 1) Acetaminophen 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth four times a day as needed *do Not take more than 4,000mg a day of acetaminophen From all sources due to risk of liver damage. 2) Albuterol 100/Ipratro 20Mcg 120D Po Inhl Inhale 1 spray by mouth four times a day (each inhaler Contains 120 sprays) 3) Allopurinol 100Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 4) Aspirin 325Mg Ec Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 5) Buspirone Hcl 10Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth twice a day as needed for anxiety 6) Capsaicin 0.1% Cream Apply a small amount topically twice a day 7) Clopidogrel Bisulfate 75Mg Tab Take one tablet every day 8) Diphenhydramine Hcl 25Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth four times a day as needed 9) Fluoxetine Hcl 10Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth every day 10) Fluticas 500/Salmeterol 50 Inhl Disk 60 Inhale 1 inhalation by mouth twice a day rinse mouth and Spit after use. Discard 1 month after opening foil pouch. 11) Folic Acid 1Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 12) Glipizide 5Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth twice a day for diabetes. Take 30 Minutes before a meal. 13) Hydrochlorothiazide 25Mg Tab Take two tablets by mouth every morning for blood pressure 14) Hydrocortisone 1% Cream Apply thin film topically every day 15) Ibuprofen 400Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth three times a day as needed 16) Insulin Reg 100U/ml Inj 10Ml Vl Inject 5 units subcutaneously as directed 17) Metformin Hcl 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 18) Metoprolol Succinate 25Mg Sa Tab Take two tablets by mouth every day 19) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day 20) Omeprazole 20Mg Ec Cap Take one capsule by mouth every day 21) Pioglitazone Hcl 15Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 22) Pravastatin Na 80Mg Tab Take one-half tablet by mouth every evening to lower your Cholesterol 23) Tamsulosin Hcl 0.4Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth at bedtime 24) Tiotropium 18Mcg Inhl Cap 30 Place 1 capsule (18 mcg) in inhaler, inhale by mouth every Day replaces ipratropium (atrovent/combivent), for Inhaler use only
Active Non-VA Medications: ============================================================ 1) Acetaminophen 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth 2) Amiodarone Hcl (Pacerone) 200Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 3) Aspirin Take by mouth every day 4) Clopidogrel Bisulfate 75Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth 5) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day
You have 29 active medications
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Your Primary Care Provider is: Unknown
#FUTURE APPOINTMENTS: Future Appointments: No future appointments on file
#LABS that were ordered today: No pending labs.
#IMAGING STUDIES that were ordered in the last 3 months: NO recent pending Radiology found.
+ If an imaging study (ultrasound, CT, MRI, etc) has been ordered, please call the Portland VA Medical Center Imaging Scheduling number to make arrangements: 503-273-5126.
#CONSULTS or PROCEDURES that were ordered in the past week: NO recent pending Consults found.
Your health care team may have discussed whether or not you were exposed to any potential toxins/hazards during your military service during this visit.
This is related to a new Toxic Exposure Screening (TES) program in the VA. If you believe you were exposed to potential toxins/hazards during your service, you can go here to learn more about what the VA is doing to support our Veterans: https://www.warrelatedillness.va.gov/WARRELATEDILLNESS/education/local-off erings/support/ToxicExposureScreeningEnglish.pdf
If you believe you were exposed to agent orange, burn pits, other airborne hazards, radiation, or served in Gulf War theaters, you may be eligible to participate in a free registry exam. You may call 503-906-5100 for more information.
For Healthcare Eligibility and Enrollment questions, contact our Enrollment Office at 503-273-5069.
For questions about Benefits and Claims you can find a Veteran Service Organization Office near you at: https://www.ebenefits.va.gov/ebenefits/vso-search or by calling VBA 1-800-827-1000.
If you are interested in physical therapy, please call the number below to arrange an appointment: All clinics: (503)273-5018
Your vitals for today are: Blood Pressure - 125/80 (01/08/2020 14:27) Weight - 255 lb [115.67 kg] (01/08/2020 14:27) Pain Level - 0 (01/08/2020 14:27) _______________________________________________________________________
If you have questions or concerns after today, please contact the clinic by calling 1-800-949-1004. Select option 2 when the automated message starts.

noteTO.text:
LOCAL TITLE: DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS - MEDICINE MULTIDISCIPLINARY STANDARD TITLE: INTERNAL MEDICINE DISCHARGE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: FEB 20, 2020@10:55 ENTRY DATE: FEB 20, 2020@10:55:47 AUTHOR: TESTjones,LISA M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
___________________________________________________________
YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL FOR ___________________________________________________________ #COPD EXACERBATION: You have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a permanent lung condition that can make it hard to empty the air out of the lungs. It can lead to shortness of breath and a feeling of being tired. Sometimes the breathing troubles in COPD can get worse over a short period of time, from just a few hours up to a week or two. We call this an exacerbation, or flare up. Often this is from an infection in the breathing tubes, but sometimes we don't know why it happens.
You are being sent home with the following to treat the flare up and help keep your lungs as healthy as possible in the future:
+ Pulmonary Rehabilitation, a program with exercise and education to help improve your lung health - you will receive a separate call to plan when and where this program will happen. +Oxygen +Inhaled breathing treatments to open up your breathing tubes
It is important for you to take your COPD medications as prescribed to prevent more flare ups and to help you breathe as best as you can every day. Most importantly, if you smoke, the best thing you can do for your lung disease is to stop smoking. Let your provider know if you are interested in quitting smoking because the VA has many ways we can help you. You should also get your flu vaccination every fall and talk to your primary care provider about the pneumonia vaccination.
___________________________________________________________
Date of admission: FEB 20,2020 07:44 Date of discharge: Feb 20,2020
Your Hospital Care Team:
Attending Physician: TESTjones,LISA M No Resident Physician Assigned.
Your hospital ward and contact phone number: 503-220-8262 or 1-800-949-1004 5C, extension 56105
If you have urgent questions about your hospital stay that need to be answered in the next 1-2 business days, please call the number above to reach a member of your hospital care team for help. After 2 business days, or for questions not related to this hospital stay, your primary care team can be contacted at the number listed in the "Your Follow-Up Care Plan" section of this note.
If you have any of these symptoms please call us or go to the Emergency Department: 1. You have a temperature greater than 101.5 degrees F 2. Your symptoms worsen or do not improve 3. You experience chest pain or shortness of breath
___________________________________________________________
YOUR FOLLOW-UP CARE PLAN ___________________________________________________________
#PENDING LAB TESTS: You have no studies that are pending from this hospital visit.
#LABS TO BE COMPLETED AFTER DISCHARGE You do not need any labs to be done after this hospital visit.
#IMAGING AND OTHER STUDIES TO BE COMPLETED AFTER DISCHARGE: You do not need any imaging or other studies to be done after this hospital visit.
#FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS: You will receive a follow up call in 1-3 days from a nurse to check on how you are doing. You may also need other follow up care appointments. These will be listed below:
+FOLLOW UP CARE WITH YOUR PRIMARY CARE TEAM: You may reach your Primary Care Team by calling 1-800-949-1004
You will need an appointment with your Primary Care Team in 1-2 months to Dr Primary Care
This may be a phone or in clinic visit. Your Primary Care Team will arrange this with you. If you have not heard from your Primary Care Team in one week, call them at the number listed above.
+HOSPITAL SPECIALTY CONSULTS: You do not need to follow up with any specialist for this hospital stay
___________________________________________________________
HOW TO TAKE CARE OF YOURSELF AT HOME ___________________________________________________________ #DIET: Low Sodium (see handout) Heart Healthy Diet (see handout)
#YOUR ACTIVITY LEVEL: You may be a little tired when you first get home. Slowly increase your activity level back to what you did before you got sick. This includes walking, climbing stairs, and exercising.
Home Oxygen:
You are going home with a prescription for oxygen. You are to use:
2 liters per minute when resting
3 liters per minute with activity
2 liters per minute when sleeping
Other:
If needed, a portable oxygen tank will be given to you for the trip home.
Please read the safety information in the "Handbook for Oxygen Therapy".
The oxygen vendor will visit you at home to give you the equipment you need.
#SUPPORT WE ORDERED FOR YOU AT HOME: Home Health You should be contacted by the VA or the community agency who will be providing your care in the next week. They will schedule a first in home meeting with you at that time. If you have not heard from the VA or the community agency in the next week, please call 503-220-8262 extension 31739 or 1-800-949-1004 extension 31739 for help.
#VETERANS CRISIS LINE: Dealing with illness can be a difficult experience. You are not alone. If you are in emotional distress or having thoughts of harming yourself, you should:
1. Come to the Portland VA Emergency Department, or 2. Call 911, or 3. Call the Veterans Crisis Line at 800-273-8255 (TALK); remember to press 1 as a Veteran, or Send a text message to 838255
#ADVANCED CARE PLANNING: When you are seriously ill, it is very important to make sure your loved ones and doctors know what kinds of medical treatment you want when you approach the end of your life. Physician Orders for Life-Sustaining Treatment (POLST) can help do just that.
POLST is a form that clearly states what kinds of medical treatment patients want toward the end of their lives. We completed a POLST for you during this admission. It is scanned into your health record. If you want to make changes to it in the future, your primary care team can help you.
--------------------------------------------------------------------- This discharge plan was developed by your Hospital Care Team, and the supervising physician agrees with the plan as outlined in this note. ---------------------------------------------------------------------
/es/ LISA M TESTjones, M.D. Staff Physician Signed: 02/20/2020 11:07

approvedBy.name: TESTjones,LISA M
approvedBy.signature: LISA M TESTjones, M.D. Staff Physician
